QE tutor Philip teaching a QE student
Welcome to Queen Elizabeth Academy, where we provide high quality Algebra 2 tutoring in San Francisco for students who are attending high school. If you are seeking a Algebra 2 tutor in San Francisco, you have come to the right place!

How can our Algebra 2 tutor in San Francisco help you?

Algebra 2 is a challenging subject. It is cummulative in a sense that, if you miss the foundation or have gaps, the next year you will run into the same problem.

So building foundation is the first step.

Memorizing steps and equations doesn't work in Algebra 2. You need to start with the foundation and understanding.

The next step is to go through a variety of problems and learn important problem solving skills. With good explanation and a solid understanding, and with practice, you will do better and enjoy Algebra 2.

Tutoring Team in San Francisco

QEA Math Teacher

Nikki is a certified teacher with Master degree in Education from University of Toronto. She has been working with QEA for over 6 years, and many of QEA top students came out of her class

QE Active Teaching approach

Learn based tutoring focuses on understanding, not memorizing

  • Review foundations that you must know for Algebra I so you don't lose marks on foundation errors

  • Review on-going curriculum. Going over homework problems

  • Go through homework from your school

  • Go through our application / thinking problems with the difficulty on par with the school tests

  • Test strategies - Prepare you to write tests and exams, with strategies on multiple choice, short answers and challenging problems

How to get high marks in Algebra 2?

Algebra 2 Tutoring in San Francisco

Common challenges for students learning Algebra 2

Algebra 2 is a very difficult, where students will start learning many advanced concepts such as logarithms and polynomials. It's difficult because each of these concepts contain many parts and they are inte-related. Students will need to understand the concepts and know how to apply to many differentsutations, as well as knowing what equation to use.

Students with weak foundation from Algebra 1 will find this course especially difficult. These include factoring, graphing techniques, linear systems, trigonometry. Students with these foundation gaps will make mistake across the tests and exams. On the surface, it looks like careless errors, but it's foundation weaknesses.

Oftentimes the first 2-3 steps of a problems belong to new concepts, then the remaining steps relate to foundation knowledge, such as simplying algebra or solving an equation. Therefore students with foundation gaps will lose marks everywhere.

QE approach to tutoring Algebra 2 in San Francisco

We start with the foundation review, making sure that the student understands the key foundation components described above. The next step is our lesson based approach that starts wtih the concepts. The student must understand the concepts. To understand the concept, it means for a student to know the "why" behind certain steps, and what are you trying to do when you perform certain operations.

Once the student understands the concept, the next step is to go over a variety of problems, step by step. The key is to explain the rationale behind the questions. Because the problems are advance in Algebra 2, it is important for students to get exposed to a variety of problems and knowing how they are related to the core concepts.

Once the student understand these, things will fall together, and Algebra 2 will be much easier.

With good lesson and practice, you will certainly excel in Algebra 2!

Enhance your study with QE Math Tutoring San Francisco

How do you study more effectively with our Math tutoring in San Francisco? The key lies in a good team work with our math tutors in San Francisco. QE will provide good lessons so that you can understand the concepts. This will give you a boost in your confidence. But remember, if you want to excel math, merely getting good math tutoring lessons isn’t enough. You need to spend time and practice. This consistent effort that you put in will distinguish you from a top student and an average student.

Inquiry for Algebra Tutoring San Francisco: 1 (888) 336 0885

How to get the most out of QE Math Tutoring San Francisco

Math tutoring San Francisco

1. Read ahead

It is important for you to know what you don’t know. This involves reading ahead before the tutoring session. Our Math tutors in San Francisco will explain to you the concepts during our lessons and attempt to find out your gaps. However, it will be very effective if you know your gaps ahead of time. All our top students do that, they read ahead, circle on the parts they don’t understand, and seek clarifications right away.

Inquiry for Algebra Tutoring San Francisco: 1 (888) 336 0885

2. Make your own study notes

After the sessions in our Math tutoring in San Francisco, we advise you to write your own notes. To start off, you can screenshot your lessons our math tutors in San Francisco write on screen, when it’s conducted online. You can then organize it. From our lessons, read over the textbook and try out the practice questions. You can then summarize in your own words, with the example questions you attempted. Why not just rely on QE math tutor’s notes? Yes you can do this, but you can understand much better if you summarize them in your own words, and you can apply better on tests.

Inquiry for Algebra Tutoring San Francisco: 1 (888) 336 0885

3.How to manage your time better with QE Math Tutors in San Francisco?

Time management is a key to your success, especially when you enter senior high school grades. The key to time management is to dedicate a time that you can put 100% of your efforts in your studies. We recommend you to use a calendar, so you can visualize your plan.

All our top students do this. You can pencil down a dedicated time, say Mon to Fri 5-6pm, for math, or other subjects. During this time, you take out all the distractions - turn off your phone, wifi, and focus solely on your work. You want to dedicate 100% of your effort to your work. QE Math tutors in San Francisco will provide you with homework, plus you get the ones from your school. Therefore, you time in making your own study notes and practice through the homework is important.

Inquiry for Algebra Tutoring San Francisco: 1 (888) 336 0885

If I am doing poorly, how can I use the help from QE Math tutoring in San Francisco?

If you aren’t performing well in the subject, chances are you have foundation gaps. The first step is really to address your foundation gaps. That’s also one of the focus on QE Math tutors in San Francisco. Once we discover your gaps during the tutoring session, we will re-teach you that particular component. Take an example, a lot of grade 11 and 12 students struggle with factoring, that’s one of the common foundation gaps. We will then re-teach it. Now, once you understand how to perform it, you need to practice at least 10-15 questions, so it sinks with you.

The next step is to review the lessons after the tutoring session. The best way is to write your own study notes. Then you need to practice homework problems. If you do all these 3 things, you will see measurable improvements from QE Math tutoring in San Francisco.

Inquiry for Algebra Tutoring San Francisco: 1 (888) 336 0885

If I am doing well, and want to achieve higher to enter the top universities, how can I use QE Math tutoring in San Francisco?

QE have such good track records, on our students to Waterloo, Laurier, Queen’s, Western and McGill. We know the process and what it takes. To maintain a good grade, you need to schedule dedicated time to your study. Practice is really key. QE Math tutors in San Francisco will provide you with good lessons and if you are already achieving 80%+, then we will focus on the tough, application / thinking problems. The challenge for these types of problems is that your teachers always change the questions on tests. It is imperative for you to practice a variety of problems, and with the explanation from QE tutors in San Francisco, you will understand how to apply your knowledge on tests.

Keep in mind that, if you are aiming for the top schools, they are very competitive. You need to always keep up the work, and with the support from QE Math tutors in San Francisco - You can do it!

FAQ for Math Tutoring San Francisco

What grade level is algebra 2?

It's grade 11.

Do colleges care if you take algebra 2?

Most colleges require Algebra 2 as they consider it a reliable predictor of college enrollment, as is commonly recognized by high schools and colleges.

Is algebra 2 math hardest?

Algebra 2 is inherently more difficult than Algebra 1 because it combines and expands upon previous math concepts while also introducing new miscellaneous concepts.

Is algebra 2 easy or hard?

To be honest, Algebra 2 can be a challenging course for students, as it introduces new and abstract concepts that may be difficult to comprehend without a certain level of mathematical maturity. However, a solid foundation in geometry can aid in developing this maturity.

Can I skip algebra 2?

Completing Algebra II is not a mandatory requirement for high school graduation as per state law. Nonetheless, a student who fails to successfully complete an Algebra II course may face certain repercussions.

Does algebra 2 prepare you for calculus?

To be honest, aside from having a basic understanding of algebra and trigonometry, there are no other prerequisites necessary to learn calculus. While the concepts of calculus do not necessarily require Algebra 2, it is typically a prerequisite for taking a calculus course. On the other hand, the material covered in precalculus is generally already covered in either Algebra 2 or calculus.

Is algebra 2 even useful?

Subjects such as Algebra 2 act as a building block towards Calculus, which is primarily necessary for students interested in pursuing careers in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics).

What is the hardest part of algebra 2?

Complete the Square.
Solve the Quadratic.
Conic Sections.
Irrational Numbers in the Denominator.
Logarithmic Functions and Exponents.

Is algebra 3 a thing?

Algebra 3 is a course that delves further into the study of Algebra and Trigonometry. The curriculum includes topics such as linear equations and inequalities, polynomials, factoring, rational expressions, as well as exponential, logarithmic, trigonometric, and inverse trigonometric functions and identities.

Why do so many students fail algebra?

For numerous students, Algebra can be an intimidating subject, as it may be the first time they encounter variables, abstract concepts, and require creative problem-solving skills. Additionally, there is often a lack of effort in the classroom to relate Algebra to real-life situations and explain its importance.
